subitem.desc: The hourglass ritual can be used to extend a buff to a significantly longer duration. It adds 180 seconds plus an additional 180 seconds for each Buff Power modifier included in the same spell stage as the buff.

subitem.name: Hourglass Ritual (Watery Grave)
subitem.desc: The hourglass ritual can be used to extend a buff to a significantly longer duration. It adds 180 seconds plus an additional 180 seconds for each Buff Power modifier included in the same spell stage as the buff.

subitem.name: Hourglass Ritual (Shrink)
subitem.desc: The hourglass ritual can be used to extend a buff to a significantly longer duration. It adds 180 seconds plus an additional 180 seconds for each Buff Power modifier included in the same spell stage as the buff.

subitem.name: Hourglass Ritual (Call Rain)
subitem.desc: The hourglass ritual can be used to modify the banish rain spell to instead call rain forth.

subitem.name: Recall to Gateway
subitem.desc: The ringed cross ritual can be used to re-target the Recall spell so you travel to a specified gateway instead of your marked location. The three runes used need to match a gateway combination. The chalk and runes will be consumed as part of the teleportation.

subitem.name: Recall Other
subitem.desc: The ringed cross ritual can be used to re-target the Recall spell so you pull another player to you. The combination can be obtained by the player using the True Sight spell, and can vary in length from player to player. Be careful when giving out your player rune combination, as it can be used to target you specifically. This recall also works cross-dimensionally.

subitem.name: Otherworldly Ritual
subitem.desc: The ringed cross ritual can be used to re-activate an #5Inert Spawner#0 in an interesting way. It causes the spawner to turn into an #5Otherworldly Aura#0!

mob.name: Hecate
mob.desc: The hecate is a dark spirit from the nether. Occasionally, the walls between the Nether and the Overworld can weaken, allowing the Hecates to spawn in the overworld. The hecate is an assassin - it moves extremely fast and can turn invisible briefly when attacking. They deal a large amount of damage, but thankfully don't have much in terms of resilience It's rumored that if you move slowly and quietly enough, you can pass by them undetected as long as you don't get too close.

mob.name: Mana Elemental
mob.desc: The mana elemental is a combination of vinteum shards held together by bolts of Etherium. They are towering creatures, often reaching 3m in height. They attack with bolts of raw mana that lash out, dealing minor damage but stealing mana, and return to the elemental, healing it based on the amount of mana stolen. They are highly resistant to physical damage. If all the mana is drained from the elemental, it will die.

mob.name: Mana Creeper
mob.desc: The mana creeper is a variant on the normal creeper, but instead of a violent explosion, the mana creeper disintegrates into a mana vortex, which will drain the mana of everything nearby. The vortex grows the longer it lives, but luckily all of them don't last for more than a few seconds. The vortex drains more mana the more you have, so it is still a threat to even the most powerful of magi.

mob.name: Light Mage
mob.desc: Light magi are part of the white council. They are powerful mages who have dedicated themselves to the forces of light. They will heal friendly players and assist them in combat against the various enemies that plague the world of Minecraft. They have a special distaste for Dark Mages.

mob.name: Dark Mage
mob.desc: Dark magi are part of the Black Court. They are sinister casters who are capable of terrifying feats of magic. These feats come at a price though, dark magi are reviled and twisted beings. They will fight anything living except the undead (which tehnically aren't "living" anyways) and creepers. They will go out of their way to fight a Light Mage.

mob.name: Fire Elemental
mob.desc: Fire elementals are beings of pure fire. They are destructive and ignite anything in their path. Fire Elementals are only found in the nether.

mob.name: Water Elemental
mob.desc: Water elementals are beings of pure water. They are found anywhere water is in abundance. They attack in groups, using water to push and pull their target. They can affect their targets with Watery Grave, which will pull unsuspecting down to the crushing black depths.

mob.name: Earth Elemental
mob.desc: Earth elementals are found slumbering deep within caves. They are passive by nature, and boast an extreme resistance to physical damage. Combined with a high health pool, anyone learning to summon one could conjure up a veritable tank. Their attacks force the target to focus on them and they will try to bounce from target to target.

mob.name: Dryad
mob.desc: Dryads are peaceful creatures often found in forests and grasslands. They can be lured with a sapling and will periodically make nearby plants grow faster.

mob.name: Darkling
mob.desc: Darklings are small dog-like creatures that are found in the nether. Their body becomes less visible during night, fading to near invsibility at midnight. As dawn approaches, the Darklings will begin to gradually appear again until they become fully visible again for the day.

mob.name: Hell Cow
mob.desc: Moo? Moo moo moo, moo moo moo moo. Moo. Moo moo moo moo moo, moo moo moo? Moo! Moo moo moo moo moo - moo moo moo. !d 1.) Moo moo moo moo !d 2.) Moo, moo moo moo moo. !d 3.) Moo! !d Moo, moo moo moo, moo moo moo. Moo moo moo moo moo moo. Moo, moo!

mob.name: Flickers
mob.desc: Flickers are lesser elementals from the various elemental planes that have crossed over into our world. Their magical bond is tenuous at best and they are known for "Flicking" back and forth between their plane and ours. They are the starting point for #5Ars Magica Automation#0. !d Flickers are timid by nature and will flick back to their own dimension if attacked, or if they feel threatened. Giving them a modicum of magic in the form of #5some sort of lasting effect#0 makes them feel more comfortable and less likely to run away. #5Flickers can be captured inside of a Flicker Jar#0. !d There is one type of flicker for each affinity. Flickers of each affinity will behave differently. For example, Air Flickers tend to like to stay higher above the ground, while Earth Flickers will prefer to stay low. !d Flickers of each affinity can be found near regions of the world that remind them of their affinity.

subitem.name: Water Flicker
subitem.desc: #5Water Flickers#0 will be found in areas that are predominantly water, like swmaps, rivers, and oceans.

subitem.name: Air Flicker
subitem.desc: #5Air Flickers#0 can be found anywhere not underground, and will fly around higher in the sky (~25 blocks above the ground).

subitem.name: Earth Flicker
subitem.desc: #5Earth Flickers#0 can be found anywhere, but they prefer underground locations. They will stay close to the ground.

subitem.name: Fire Flicker
subitem.desc: #5Fire Flickers#0 can be found in the nether..

subitem.name: Lightning Flicker
subitem.desc: #5Lightning Flickers#0 can be found on beaches and over oceans in the sky, where storms like to form. They can be found in all areas if it is storming.

subitem.name: Nature Flicker
subitem.desc: #5Nature Flickers#0 can be found in forests.

subitem.name: Ice Flicker
subitem.desc: #5Ice Flickers#0 can be found in frozen areas, such as Taiga.

subitem.name: Arcane Flicker
subitem.desc: #5Arcane Flickers#0 can be found in magical areas. They very much like Witchwood Forests.

subitem.name: Life Flicker
subitem.desc: #5Life Flickers#0 can be found anywhere. Any flicker spawning has a small chance to be a life flicker rather than whatever else it could be.

subitem.name: Ender Flicker
subitem.desc: #5Ender Flickers#0 are found in the end. Occasionally, a teleporting Enderman can open a rift large enough for Ender Flickers to slip through.

subitem.name: XyCraft Flicker
subitem.desc: #5XyCraft Flickers#0 are implemented, but don't do anything yet.

boss.name: Nature Guardian
boss.desc: The Nature Guardian is a fearsome opponent. Boasting a deadly scythe and the skill to use it, only the most powerful or foolish would seek it out. The few who have survived an encounter state that it is just as dangerous at range as in melee, if not more. !l Recommended level: 60 !p Rumor has it that it appears to guard the servants of nature when enough are slain in quick succession. Nature can be harsh, but it will not tolerate a massacre. !d Warning: !l This is a very difficult boss that can take down even the most well geared players.

boss.name: Earth Guardian
boss.desc: Formed out of a core of stone, the Earth Guardian is a hardy opponent that can withstand incredible amounts of physical attacks. With whirling attacks and strength of the earth itself, be prepared for a fight. !l Recommended level: 25 !p To summon the Earth Guardian, first build a 3x3 obsidian platform with a chiseled stone brick at the centre. On top of the obsidian, build an iron inlay ring. Off of each side, on the same level as the inlays, place a vinteum torch. Then throw in a blue topaz, an emerald, and a chimerite. !d Upon summoning, the Earth Guardian will cleave out a large area of the surrounding blocks, so it would be wise to summon somewhere other than your basement.

boss.name: Water Guardian
boss.desc: The guardian of water is a unique being. It is always in a state of fluidity, making it able to shrug off attacks occasionally. It is a trickster as well, flowing into copies of itself and attacking from ambush if one is fooled by the decoy. !l Recommended level: 10 !p The water guardian can be summoned by creating a redstone inlay circle in any biome that is predominantly water. Then, while raining, throw a boat and a bucket of water into the circle as homage to the many ships lost at sea.

boss.name: Winter Guardian
boss.desc: The Winter Guardian is truly the embodiment of it's namesake. Surrounded by frigid winds that sap the strength of all who near it, the Winter Guardian pummels its frozen foes and shatters them with powerful strikes. !p To summon the Winter Guardian, seek out an area in the grips of winter. Place a gold inlay circle on the ground and build an effigy to the Winter Guardian in the centre, Ice on top of two Blue Topaz blocks. Then create 3 snow golems close by to fuel the summoning. !d Warning: !l This is a very difficult boss that can take down even the most well geared players.

boss.name: Arcane Guardian
boss.desc: A mage of ancient times, the Arcane Guardian has access to a wide variety of spells. From attacks to buffs to debuffs, prepare for a magical duel that will test your counterspell knowledge. Protected by a powerful sigil, the Arcane Guardian has as many tricks against melee opponents as it does against ranged attackers. !l Recommended level: 45 !p To summon the Arcane Guardian, first construct a Shrine of Knowledge. The shrine is 2 pillars of bookshelves, 3 high, with a lectern on the ground in between them containing an Arcane Compendium. Place an iron inlay circle directly in front of the structure, and throw an Arcane Essence directly in the middle of the circle to start the ritual.

boss.name: Air Guardian
boss.desc: The Air Guardian is a being of wind, and makes heavy use of knockback based attacks. It would be foolish to go into battle with one without some form of falling protection. The Air Guardian is a powerful ranged caster, but it requires a great deal of focus to finish some of it's spells... !l Recommended level: 35 !p To summon the Air Guardian, climb up well above the clouds and build a platform (y 150 or higher). Build a gold inlay ring on the platform and throw in an Air Essence.

boss.name: Fire Guardian
boss.desc: The Fire Guardian is a living inferno from the depths of the nether. To summon it, create a gold inlay ring in the nether on top of obsidian with a coal block in the middle. Throw a water essence onto the coal and the fire guardian will appear. Be warned though, it does not take kindly to those that try to bring water to its domain. Be prepared for a fight! !l Recommended level: 90

boss.name: Life Guardian
boss.desc: The life guardian generally prefers to let the natural order of things take their course, not intervening unless a true sacriledge against life is performed. Luckily (or unluckily, depending on how you look at it) for you, you have come up with a way to commit such an act. Create a 5x5 ring using wizard's chalk, and place a warding candle in the center part of each side, on the outside of the ring (4 candles in total). The circle will help to contain and focus the deed. Then, on the night of a full moon, sacrifice a villager child inside the circle. That should be enough to anger the life guardian to action. !d You monster you. !p The life guardian doesn't attack much on its own, though it may decide to throw you around a little. It generally prefers to let others do the fighting for it, infusing them with its tremendous power. In return, the others will often lay down their lives for the guardian's protection. The life guardian is a different kind of fight than the other guardians. !d Recommended level: 50

boss.name: Lightning Guardian
boss.desc: The lightning guardian is as unpredictable as it is powerful. It can fire bolts of lightning at extreme range, and has been known to mess with the synapses inside the brains of living creatures. It has also on occasion been able to replicate an effect similar to telekinesis using massive amounts of concentrated static electricity, which leaves the unfortunate victim open to several other effects. !d To summon the lightning guardian, create a #5Gold Inlay Ring#0 and place a mana battery in the middle. Then, place 2 iron bars on top, creating a lightning rod. !d Finally, wait for a storm. !d This guardian is capable of doing extreme damage in a short amount of time. Make sure you are well protected. Recommended Level: 70

boss.name: Ender Guardian
boss.desc: Tales are told in hushed whispers of the true guardian of the End. Of eyes glowing with an abhorrent light, and scaly skin as black as a moonless night. Alas, the tales of this waking nightmare are vague at best and always shrouded in the veil of speculation. The truth is, nobody has ever seen the guardian and lived. The most common tale is that of Magnus Severinus, the Archmage of the Second Era. At the height of his power, he was rumored to be able to move mountains with a thought, create lush gardens out of the most barren terrain, and create wards that could stop an army cold. Alas, his most trusted advisor took ill, and her spiteful stepson had taken her place. Goaded by honeyed words encouraging his power and making him arrogant, he gathered the conclave together and in front of them all, tore open the fabric between worlds, opening a portal to the end that pulsed with a soft purple glow that almost seemed to draw light away from its surroundings. He stepped in, and summoned the guardian. He never had time to scream. A piece of paper, flecked with bits of dark blood, flitted back through the portal and it winked shut. Upon the paper was the following ritual: !d In the End, around a black aurem atop a platform of blackest coal, create an inlay of gold. Light a burning fire on each side of the inlay. Throw in an Ender Essence and an Eye of Ender to destabilize the aurem and summon the guardian. !d The paper was locked away in magical valuts and forgotten for millenia...until now.

block.name: Illusion Blocks
block.desc: Illusion blocks are so realistic that your brain will not allow you to walk through them due to self preservation and common sense. Only with true sight can you convince yourself that the illusion is not real, and pass through to the other side. !l "Is that it?" !l "No. That's a wall." !l "It could be disguised." !l "You're not very good at looking for things, are you?" !l "I'm good at looking for walls. Look, I found another one."

subitem.name: Illusion Block
subitem.desc: Standard illusion blocks will look and function as solid blocks unless the entity attempting to pass through has #9True Sight#0 active.

subitem.name: Ethereal Illusion Block
subitem.desc: Ethereal illusion blocks will look like solid blocks, but anything can pass through them. They still will emit particles if you have #9True Sight#0 active. Ethereal Illusion Blocks will not change their appearance due to True Sight though.

block.name: Essence Refiner
block.desc: The essence refiner takes everyday items and using #5Arcane Ash#0, refines them into a pure representation of their parts, known as #5essences#0. The recipes for specific essences can be found under #9Items -> Essences#0. The essence refiner also requires #2Etherium#0 to function. Neutral Etherium can be obtained from an #9Obelisk#0, which has no specific advantages or drawbacks. Finally, Dark Etherium can be used from a #9Black Aurem#0, which significantly reduces the amount of time it takes to refine the essence. The spinning ring on the UI will shift from blue to purple as the refinement process progresses and eventually completes. A flashing red ring means there is insufficient Etherium to continue, and the process has been paused.

block.name: Etherium Conduit
block.desc: Infused with dusts to direct Etherium through the air, the Etherium Conduit began seeing heavy use almost immediately after its invention. They can be used to transfer Etherium over longer distances than the direct range of Etherium generation apparatus. Each one has a range of 10 blocks, and can form chains to move Etherium up to 100 blocks away from the origin.

block.name: Caster Blocks
block.desc: A spell is nothing more than directed essence. The will of a magic user dictates what the essence does, and if they have enough capacity for essence, the magic will flow forth. The caster was designed to replicate that ability, converting raw essence into a burst of magic that is directed through a spell focus (as well as the occasional mana focus) and shaped via the instructions on a spell scroll. Because of the extreme essence draw of certain spells, the internal crystals were fitted with a slot to allow a charge focus which causes the amount of incoming essence to be increased substantially. Alternately, a mana focus can be fitted into the same slots, causing the internal essence routing to be much more efficient.

subitem.name: Caster Rune
subitem.desc: The Caster Rune functions in the same way as a #5Caster#0, save for one specific difference: The caster rune does not required a redstone signal to operate, and rather casts when walked upon. It will cast directly on whatever triggers it.

block.name: Seer Stone
block.desc: Operating on a similar principle as the Astral Barrier, the Seer Stone uses an Etherium aura projected through a spell focus to detect nearby objects. It can be controlled by focusing the Etherium to a particular type of object, and the resonant frequency of the Etherium can be dictated with the use of a rune combination. Without the use of a rune combination, the resonant frequency fluxuates unpredictably and cannot be avoided. The seer stone, however, is meant for a more subtle approach, letting the object continue, but emitting a small signal that often activates much more powerful defenses. By sneaking up and activating the stone, one can even (if he has the correct key of course) cause the stone to invert its detection methods, detecting those with the matching keystone combination. !d Different #5Foci#0 can be used in the Seer Stone. #5Lesser, Standard, and Greater foci#0 change the detection distance of the stone (5, 10, or 15 blocks respectively), while #5Item, Player, Monster, or Creature foci#0 can change what the seer stone is looking for. Without a target focus and a distance focus, the seer stone will not function. !d A keystone is searched for in the case of a player. If the player has a keystone in their inventory matching the rune combination in the seer stone, the seer stone will ignore them and will not trigger.

block.name: Astral Barrier
block.desc: When walking the void, one must be aware of barriers. Projecting an Etherium aura through a spell focus, these barriers resonate at a specific magical frequency, dictated by a keytstone. Without the proper matching keystone, these barriers will destabilize your magics and force you out of the void. Should the astral barrier not have a keystone present, its magic frequency will fluxuate unpredictably, and no amount of Keystones can protect you from its effects. Several Dark Magi raids have been foiled and several Light Magi have been captured due to their failure to spot the barrier in time. !d Different #5Foci#0 can be used in the Astral Barrier. #5Lesser, Standard, and Greater foci#0 change the distance of the barrier, to 5, 10, or 15 blocks respectively. Without a distance focus, the barrier will not function. !d The barrier will stop teleportation into its radius, including ender pearls, blink, mark/recall, and endermen.

block.name: Keystone Recepticle
block.desc: Not all magi are capable of walking the void as a means of travel, nor are all willing. The void is detectable, blockable. Gateways were developed by the Dark Magi early in the war, and it allowed them to take many Light Mage encampments by surprise, as it uses alternate pathways to transport to its destination. Astral Barriers were ineffective at stopping the arrival of the Dark Magi, and the destination gate required no power of its own. The Light Magi destroyed as many as they could find, but the Dark Magi only needed one. The only hope was when a young Light Mage by the name of Damien Callitri discovered that the gateways could be locked down if a Keystone was inserted into a flaw in the design at just the right spot in the gateway mechanism, and would actually cause the gateway to send the Dark Mages to a different gateway (or nowhere if none others existed that weren't locked down). This halted the raids completely, and allowed the White Magi to turn the tides back in their favour, as they could actually use the gateways to return to their keystone gate. The design flaw became jokingly known as the "Keystone Recepticle" amongst the White Magi.

block.name: Vinteum Ore
block.desc: Vinteum was discovered during a heated battle between the Light and Dark magi when a stray arcane bolt collided with an ender bolt. The resulting explosion created a crater several meters deep, where a sparkling blue ore shimmered in the light of the afternoon. It appears to have no magical properties of its own, but when heat is applied, it becomes a fine dust with an exceptional capacity to conduct Etherium. As such, it is widely used in magical contraptions all over the world.

block.name: Mana Battery
block.desc:
Drawing further on vinteum dust's ability to conduct Etherium, a small group of brilliant magi created a frame out of vinteum-infused chimerite which is capable of storing massive amounts of Etherium. Mana batteries will always provide power to connected devices, but they can also request Etherium from the network when given a redstone signal.
Unfortunately, the process used to manufacture the battery makes it somewhat volatile, causing it to lose all stored Etherium if it is moved without the careful touch of a mage's hand.

block.name: Cerublossom
block.desc: Cerublossom flowers thrive in lush, green environments. They were one of the first magical plants discovered, being used in potions and salves. Cerublossom emits a faint sparkling glow of light around it as well, and was used just as much for decoration as an alchemical ingredient. A short while after its discovery, it was also noted that the Cerublossom could be used as part of the purification process for Vinteum dust.

block.name: Desert Nova
block.desc: Desert Novas grow in dry conditions. They get their name from the small bursts of magic that they periodically emit. The Nova has extraordinary magical properties for a desert plant, and is highly sought after. It is one of the two plants used in the purification process of Vinteum dust.

block.name: Keystone Chest
block.desc: The keystone chest was developed as a simple way to have a magically locked chest. When a keystone is inserted into the internal slot, in order to open it, one must have a matching keystone in their hand. By inserting the keystone into the outer lock*, the chest can be opened. If there is no keystone, the chest opens normally. !l !l * Just right click the chest with the keystone in your hand.

block.name: Magic Wall
block.desc: An early attempt at the illusion block, the magic wall wasn't really able to blend with it's surroundings. Or even prevent people from looking through. The value, though, was just after having master mage Leonidus criticize us for our efforts, watching him walk face first into one. That's when we knew it at least had the stopping power part right. But when the fireball he threw at it BOUNCED back and burnt his beard off, we knew it was a keeper.

block.name: Arcane Reconstructor
block.desc: Magic can, with the right influence, do anything. By directing Etherium at the weak spots in otherwise mundane items, the Etherium will solidify to repair the damage, making it good as new.

block.name: Lectern
block.desc: A must have for any organized mage, the Lectern is an ideal place to store books, compendiums, and thaumonomicons for easy access. The book sits perfectly where it can be read without having to remove it from the lectern. It is also a critical part of the Crafting Altar, as spell crafting does require organization.

block.name: Occulus
block.desc: A gateway to the stars, the Occulus shows you your innermost self. It is here that you can spend skill points to unlock new shapes, components, and modifiers. There are 3 kinds of skill points, which can be learned by obtaining Infinity Orbs from Dungeons, other worldgen, and Summoning Rituals. The skills, when learnable, will glow with the corresponding skill point needed to unlock it. Blue are the most common skill points, followed by Green, and finally Red.

block.name: Calefactor
block.desc: A magical furnace, the calefactor can produce vinteum dust as it cooks in addition to the smelted item. If provided with light, neutral, and dark etherium, the calefactor can double ores. It always has a small chance to double food.

block.name: Inscription Table
block.desc: Organization is a must for any mage who wants to be successful. Using this table along with a writable book, you can compose spells of incredible power. Most mages will lay out what spell parts they know at the top of the table in the Source Region, and will drag shapes and modifiers to the brown squares set aside for Shape Groups, and components to the Spell Grammar section at the bottom to lay out a spell. Once satisfied with the spell, you can write the spells down in a writable book (you did remember to bring one, didn't you?). This book can be placed upon a lectern that is part of the Crafting Altar structure, and will guide you through the process needed to make the spell. The book is worth reading too, as it contains a recap of the spell you will be creating, a materials list, and an affinity breakdown. See #5Guides -> Your First Spell#0 for more detailed information.

block.name: Particle Emitter
block.desc: Purely a decoration block, the particle emitter can be used to create a magical feel in any area. The emitter can be customized by right clicking it, and it can be hidden. If hidden, simply holding a crystal wrench while near it will cause it to be visible again. Right clicking a particle emitter with a crystal wrench in unlink mode will cause its settings to be copied. Right clicking another particle emitter while also in unlink mode will copy those settings to the second emitter.

block.name: Aum
block.desc: A flower with healing properties, Aum is a component in many spells. It can only be found at the base of witchwood trees.

block.name: Tarma Root
block.desc: Lighter than it looks, Tarma Root grows in caves and other dark places. It is an ingredient in spells, and air essences.

block.name: Wakebloom
block.desc: Growing on the surface of water in warm climates, wakebloom is used in water-based spells frequently as well as being a component in water essence.

block.name: Summoner
block.desc: The summoner takes Etherium one step farther and uses it to summon creatures to do your bidding upon receipt of a redstone signal. It has a hefty summon cost, as well as a maintain cost to keep the summon alive. If the redstone signal ever dies out or power runs out, the creature will unsummon. When the creature is unsummoned or killed, there is a short delay before it can be summoned again. Note that the summoner requires a full-fledged summon spell, not a filled crystal phylactery.

block.name: Inlays
block.desc: Inlays are runes that are used both for decoration and for summoning bosses when placed into the right pattern (see Structures). There are a few different types of Inlay.

subitem.name: Redstone Inlay
subitem.desc: Redstone inlays are the most basic of inlay. They are used to summon bosses, and can also be used as rails. They will speed up a minecart as it passes over them. Be wary when cornering too fast, as the cart can leave the tracks entirely.

subitem.name: Iron Inlay
subitem.desc: Iron inlays are an intermediate inlay. They are used to summon bosses, and can also be used as rails. When a minecart touches an iron inlay, it will reverse direction. Some of the momentum is preserved, but not all.

subitem.name: Gold Inlay
subitem.desc: Gold inlays are the most advanced inlay. They are used to summon the most powerful of bosses. They can also be used as rails. When a minecart touches a gold inlay, it will attempt to warp to the next gold inlay in the direction it is currently traveling within 8 blocks. This can transport the minecart (and any passengers) through solid obstacles, as it is in fact teleportation. There is a short delay before the minecart can teleport on a gold rail again after it warps.

block.name: Chiseled Stone Blocks
block.desc: You can create chiseled stone blocks that you need by crafting 4 stone bricks together in a 2x2 grid.

block.name: Witchwood Saplings
block.desc: Witchwood saplings can rarely be obtained from the leaves of a witchwood tree. They can be planted, however they need a source of Liquid Etherium within 1 block and below them (x/z +/- 1, y-1). The more liquid etherium source pools nearby (max 8), the faster the sapling will grow. Even with all 8, however, the grow time can be significant. Once the sapling grows into a full witchwood tree, it can sometimes also cause aum to grow nearby as well.

block.name: Crafting Altar
block.desc: Harnessing the forces of creation, the crafting altar allows mages to work miracles of magic. This is where you will create all of your spells in AM2. The crafting altar is a component of a #9multiblock structure#0.

block.name: Magician's Workbench
block.desc: The magician's workbench was born out of necessity from the large number of items mages tend to make. However, one particular mage got tired of having to clear out the crafting grid every time he forgot a sub-component, and having to run to a chest, usually dropping items along the way. This table #5has multiple crafting grids#0 that you can use simultaneously to make items. It also remembers previous crafting recipes (the most recent 8) and can restore that recipe to the crafting grid with the click of a button, provided the components are in its #5internal storage#0. There is an upgrade you can craft that will increase the size of the second grid to a 3x3 from a 2x2.

block.name: Everstone
block.desc: Everstone is a magically-infused block that can mimic other blocks much like #5illusion blocks#0 can. However, when broken, Everstone will #9not drop, but rather become incorporeal for a brief time#0. After that time, it will re-solidify and return to its original state. While it is solidifying, everstone can be passed through as if it is not there. To make it mimic a block, simply right click on the everstone with the desired block in hand. If it is not already mimicing a block, it will assume the properties of the new block. To remove the mask, simply right click the everstone with a #5Crystal Wrench#0. Right clicking an everstone that is not already mimicing a texture will cause it to drop as normal and be recovered.

block.name: Vinteum Torches
block.desc: Vinteum Torches are crafted in a simplistic way, and glow with roughly the same brightness as a standard torch. They are just an aesthetic alternative.

block.name: Slipstream Generator
block.desc: You have managed to create a device that can project a cushion of air around you to make you float upwards or gently lower down towards the ground. The machine only works on mages above it (#5players only#0), but has a large vertical range. In testing, you note that if you are falling when you enter its effect radius, it takes a little while before it can completely catch you. You have also managed to make it work #9based on the direction you are looking#0. Look up, go up. Look down, go down. Look forward, hover. You can also #9sneak to remain vertically stationary#0, regardless of where you are looking.

block.name: Obelisk
block.desc: The Obelisk is a runed block that is used to generate #5Etherium#0 (the power system in Ars Magica 2). It acts as a magical furnace, and burns Vinteum Dust or Liquid Etherium to generate power. !d It can be altered using #9Rituals#0 to become a #4Black Aurem#0 or a #9Celestial Prism#0.

block.name: Broken Power Links
block.desc: If a power path is created, and at some point a relay (conduits, etc.) or generator (obelisk, prism, aurem, etc.) is broken, the power system will attempt to let you know that there was something there, and something is amiss. These blocks will be placed automatically by the power system if a broken link is detected. The block will be placed at the point where the relay or generator used to be. !d These blocks will only ever be placed where no other block exists. They cannot be broken by hand, but can be replaced with any block. Broken power link blocks are only visible if you are wearing a pair of #9Magitech's Goggles#0.

block.name: Flicker Habitat
block.desc: The flicker habitat is a series of crystals designed to allow Flickers to remain in our world. If a #9Flicker Focus#0 is added, the flickers inside the focus will use the habitat to perform several tasks around the area, such as growing plants, sorting items, fishing, creating magical barriers, and many other functions. !d You can also place a #9Flicker Jar#0 in the habitat and it will serve to modify the functionality of adjacent habitats with a Flicker Focus in them. !d See the flicker focus entries for more information on how they can be modified.

block.name: Crystal Markers
block.desc: Crystal Markers are used to instruct Flickers inside of a Flicker Habitat on how to sort items. When wearing #9Magitech Goggles#0, you can see the priority level of the different crystals. This priority indicates the order in which the flickers will attempt to move items. Lower priority crystals are tried first. You can change the priority of any crystal by rght clicking it while holding a #9Magitech's Staff#0.

subitem.name: Import Crystal
subitem.desc: This crystal instructs the flickers to collect items from the inventory it is attached to and bring it into the item transportation network. Import crystals cannot have a priority level.

subitem.name: Export Crystal
subitem.desc: This crystal instructs the flickers that all items in the item transportation network can be exported to the inventory this crystal is attached to.

subitem.name: Mimic Export Crystal
subitem.desc: This crystal instructs the flickers that items maybe exported from the item transportation network to the inventory this crystal is attached to so long as the inventory already contains that item.

subitem.name: Set Export Crystal
subitem.desc: This crystal instructs the flickers that items may be exported from the item transportation network to the inventory this crystal is attached to so long as the item has been set through this crystal's GUI.

subitem.name: Regulate Export Crystal
subitem.desc: This crystal instructs the flickers that items may be exported from the item transportation network to the inventory this crystal is attached to so long as the item has been set through this crystal's GUI and the inventory contains less then number of items set in the crystal's GUI.

subitem.name: Regulate Bidirectional Crystal
subitem.desc: This crystal instructs the flickers that they may both import and export from the inventory this crystal is attached to !d Import: !l Flickers will take items from the inventory so long as the item has been added to this crystal's GUI and the number of items in the chest is greater then the number set in the GUI !d Export: !l Flickers will put items into the inventory so long as the item has been added to this crystal's GUI and the number of items is below the number set in the GUI.

subitem.name: Set Import Crystal
subitem.desc: This crystal instructs the flickers that they may import items into the item transportation network from the inventory this crystal is attached to so long as the item has been added to this crystal's GUI.

subitem.name: Final Export Crystal
subitem.desc: This crystal instructs the flickers that they should put any items that can't otherwise be placed in the inventory marked by this crystal. These crystals always have the highest priority number, meaning items will be placed there last.

subitem.name: Spell Export Crystal
subitem.desc: This crystal instructs the flickers to watch any crafting altar within 10 blocks. If it is crafting a spell, the flickers will attempt to fetch the next item required for the spell and place it in the inventory marked by this crystal.

block.name: Keystone Doors
block.desc: Keystone Doors can be locked using a rune combination. If locked, they will only open if you have a keystone with the matching key in your inventory. If not locked, they function simply as a door. Zombies cannot break them down either way.

block.name: Armor Imbuement Table
block.desc: The Armor Imbuement Table can be used to attach special imbuements to any armor in Minecraft. In order to do this, you first need to have the armor equipped. Mousing over any armor will display a prompt of "Press SHIFT for more information". Doing so will show you how much XP has been absorbed into the armor. Armor gains XP when you do. See #5Mechanics -> Armor XP Infusion#0 for more information on how it works. !d Once your armor has reached at least level 30, you can apply a Tier I imbuement to it. Simply equip the armor and activate the Armor Imbuement Table. Place the armor from the equip slots at the bottom of the UI into the active slot. Available imbuements will appear in colour, unavailable ones will be grayscale. You can only apply one tier of imbuement per armor piece, so choose wisely! !d The tier costs are: !l Tier 1: 30 levels !l Tier 2: 42 levels !l Tier 3: 54 levls !l Tier 4: 66 levels !d Each time you imbue the armor, XP is deducted from it to apply the imbuement.

subitem.name: Imbuement: Burnout Reduction
subitem.desc: The Burnout Reduction imbuement grants a 150% increase in the rate that your Burnout reduces. The effect is additive for each piece, with a maximum of 600%. !d Available Slots: Head, Chest, Legs, Boots

subitem.name: Imbuement: Fall Damage
subitem.desc: The Fall Damage Imbuement causes a 15% reduction in fall damage. !d Available Slots: Head, Chest, Legs, Boots

subitem.name: Imbuement: Drown Damage
subitem.desc: The Drown Damage Imbuement causes a 15% reduction in drown damage. !d Available Slots: Head, Chest, Legs, Boots

subitem.name: Imbuement: Explosive Damage
subitem.desc: The Explosive Damage Imbuement causes a 15% reduction in explosive damage. !d Available Slots: Head, Chest, Legs, Boots

subitem.name: Imbuement: Physical Damage
subitem.desc: The Physical Damage Imbuement causes a 15% reduction in physical damage. !d Available Slots: Head, Chest, Legs, Boots

subitem.name: Imbuement: Fire Damage
subitem.desc: The Fire Damage Imbuement causes a 15% reduction in fire damage. !d Available Slots: Head, Chest, Legs, Boots

subitem.name: Imbuement: Frost Damage
subitem.desc: The Frost Damage Imbuement causes a 15% reduction in frost damage. !d Available Slots: Head, Chest, Legs, Boots

subitem.name: Imbuement: Lightning Damage
subitem.desc: The Lightning Damage Imbuement causes a 15% reduction in lightning damage. !d Available Slots: Head, Chest, Legs, Boots

subitem.name: Imbuement: Magic Damage
subitem.desc: The Magic Damage Imbuement causes a 15% reduction in magic damage. !d Available Slots: Head, Chest, Legs, Boots

subitem.name: Imbuement: Mana Regeneration
subitem.desc: The Mana Regeneration Imbuement grants a 10% increase to your mana regeneration rate. !d Available Slots: Head, Chest, Legs, Boots

subitem.name: Imbuement: Magitech Goggles
subitem.desc: The Magitech Goggles Imbuement causes any helmet to grant the same attributes as the #5Magitech Goggles#0. !d Available Slots: Head

subitem.name: Imbuement: Pinpoint Ores
subitem.desc: The Pinpoint Ores Imbuement allows an extra level of precision when using a #5Warding Candle#0, causing the flame to go black when within 2 blocks of the target ore. !d Available Slots: Head

subitem.name: Imbuement: Hunger Regeneration
subitem.desc: The Hunger Regeneration Imbuement causes your hunger to passively regenerate. !d Available Slots: Head

subitem.name: Imbuement: Mining Speed
subitem.desc: The Mining Speed Imbuemnt causes you to mine blocks 50% faster. !d Available Slots: Head

subitem.name: Imbuement: Thaumic Vision
subitem.desc: #9REQUIRES THAUMCRAFT#0 !d The Thaumic Vision Imbuement causes you to see things as if you had Thaumcraft Goggles equipped. !d Available Slots: Head

subitem.name: Imbuement: Water Breathing
subitem.desc: The Water Breathing Imbuement allows you to breathe underwater for a short time if your air gets low. !d Available Slots: Head

subitem.name: Imbuement: Flicker Lure
subitem.desc: The Flicker Lure Imbuement will cause #9Flickers#0 to not flick away when you get close. !d Available Slots: Chest

subitem.name: Imbuement: Soulbound
subitem.desc: The Soulbound Imbuement will cause the item to stay with you when you die rather than being dropped. !d Available Slots: Chest, Legs, Boots

subitem.name: Imbuement: Healing
subitem.desc: The Healing Imbuement causes you go get a powerful regeneration buff if your health gets low. !d Available Slots: Chest

subitem.name: Imbuement: Life-Saving
subitem.desc: The Life Saving Imbuement will reverse death on you, causing it to not apply and restoring 50% of your health. Causes extreme damage to armor and has a long cooldown. !d Available Slots: Chest

subitem.name: Imbuement: Bonus Magic XP
subitem.desc: The Bonus Magic XP Imbuement grants 50% bonus magic XP from spell casts. !d Available Slots: Chest

subitem.name: Imbuement: Recoil
subitem.desc: The Recoil Imbuement causes any melee attacker to be violently thrown backwards away from you. !d Available Slots: Chest

subitem.name: Imbuement: Step Assist
subitem.desc: The Step Assist Imbuement allows you to step up over 1-block edges. !d Available Slots: Legs

subitem.name: Imbuement: Dispelling
subitem.desc: The Dispelling Imbuement removes any negative buff applied to you. Has a short cooldown. !d Available Slots: Legs

subitem.name: Imbuement: Lava Protection
subitem.desc: Should you fall into lava, this imbuement will proc, solidifying the lava around you into a protective dome of cobble/obsidian. !d Available Slots: Legs

subitem.name: Imbuement: Jump Boost
subitem.desc: The Jump Boost Imbuement allows you to jump significantly higher. !d Available Slots: Legs

subitem.name: Imbuement: Swim Speed Boost
subitem.desc: The Swim Speed Boost Imbuement allows you to swim significantly faster. !d Available Slots: Legs

subitem.name: Imbuement: Run Speed Boost
subitem.desc: The Run Speed Boost Imbuement allows you to run significantly faster. !d Available Slots: Boots

subitem.name: Imbuement: Fall Protection
subitem.desc: The Fall Protection Imbuement will automatically apply a slowfall effect to you right before you hit the ground, preventing all damage. It has a short cooldown. !d Available Slots: Boots

subitem.name: Imbuement: Freedom of Movement
subitem.desc: The Freedom of Movement Imbuement prevents most movement impairing effects from affecting you. !d Available Slots: Boots

subitem.name: Imbuement: Water Walking
subitem.desc: You can walk on water with these boots. You're a ninja! !d Water walking is only applied when you're on top of the water. If you're in, or under the water, you can swim as normal. Simply swim to the top of the water and jump out to start water walking. From the top of the water, start sneaking to drop down into the depths. !d Available Slots: Boots

subitem.name: Imbuement: Light Step
subitem.desc: The Light Step Imbuement automatically causes a mage light to be placed at your feet (if possible) wherever the light level is low enough for monsters to spawn. !d Available Slots: Boots

block.name: Flicker Lure
block.desc: Flickers aren't normally able to enter our world, but with a little help and incentive, you can make that happen. Placing this block and powering it with Etherium will allow flickers to be pulled into our world! When you want them, just apply a redstone signal. The type of flicker will depend on where the lure is. See the entry on #9Flickers#0 for information on where to find specific ones.

block.name: Arcane Deconstructor
block.desc: The Arcane Deconstructor, when powerd with #5Dark Etherium#0 can disassemble an item back into its crafting components. !d Oh yeah, it can also disassemble spells. You will get most of the items back from a spell, but items such as the initial blank rune or etherium investments, as well as the final spell parchment, will not be refunded. !d The deconstructor will attempt to place items into adjacent inventories if its own is full upon un-crafting. Any items that cannot be placed are simply ejected into the world.

block.name: Otherworldly Aura
block.desc: The Otherworldly Aura is used to automate spell creation. It summons a shadow copy of whoever created it to complete the spell. !d To use it, you need the following: !l -Within 10 blocks of the #5Crafting Altar#0 !l -#4Dark#0 or #9Neutral#0 Etherium (have a good amount on hand, interdimensional travel is costly!) !l -One or more block inventories (chest, hopper, etc) within 8 blocks of the Aura. These inventories are what will be searched for spell reagents. !d The aurem will maintain the shadow for as long as needed, provided it has enough power. Running out of power will cause the shadow to dissipate, and out of spite for the inconvenience, it may take whatever reagent it is currently carrying! Only one aura will assist an altar at a time, so multiple auras are not needed. !d To get the aura, perform a #5Ritual of the Cross#0 around an #5Inert Spawner#0 with #5Transplace#0 as the catalyst.

block.name: Inert Spawner
block.desc: You've managed to pick up a monster spawner, but it seems to not be able to spawn anything anymore. You should look into other applications for this device, or find a way to re-activate it. !d Perhaps #5Dark Etherium#0 and a #5Filled Crystal Phylactery#0 could make it function again...

mechanic.name: Affinities
mechanic.desc:
#5Affinity#0 represents a bond to certain areas of magic. You start with no affinity. Your affinity is represented as a small chart on the HUD, and can be viewed in more detail at an Occulus (craftable Block). Your affinity will shift based on what spells you cast, meaning as you cast certain types of spells more often, you will get better at them. Casting spells of a differing affinity will shift you towards that affinity. Once you reach 100% in an affinity, you become locked to that affinity, and will need to read an opposing affinity tome to unlock your affinity, at which point normal progression will resume. Unlocking a full affinity will drop you down to 80% depth.
Each spell component has an affinity. Components of the same affinity as you will cost less mana, and depending on your affinity depth (how far into the affinity you are), may not even cost reagents. Components of the opposing affinity, however, will cost more mana and again, depending on your affinity depth, may cost additional reagents. Affinities offer specific bonuses and disadvantages, described on the affinity-specific pages.

subitem.name: Earth Affinity
subitem.desc: Earth affinity grants a minor defense bonus, due to your hardened skin. At max, you will have 10% overall damage reduction, applied before armor. This amount depends on your affinity depth into earth, and begins at 25% depth. !d With earth affinity, you are heavier, and as such you will sink more quickly in water (though never enough that you cannot surface), and you cannot fall as far without taking fall damage.

subitem.name: Water Affinity
subitem.desc: Water affinity grants a bonus to swim speed as well as slower breath loss underwater. You are also not pushed by flowing water. Endermen that attack a full water-affinity mage will take damage as if they had touched water. !d Water affinity mages take damage periodically if exposed to fire, making the nether particularly dangerous. This damage will not take you below 75% health, and will not occur at all if you are lower.

subitem.name: Air Affinity
subitem.desc: Air affinity grants a bonus to jump height and lets you fall farther before taking damage. These bonuses are dependent on your affinity depth: you can jump one block higher and fall one block farther at 50% depth. This bonus increases to 2 at 75%, and 3 at full depth. !d Air affinity mages are hindered by rain and storms; the wind blows you around and you must move slower. #5Sneaking#0 or casting a spell of #5Gravity Well#0 can negate the effect and allow you to move in the storm, albeit slowly.

subitem.name: Fire Affinity
subitem.desc: Fire affinity grants damage reduction in fire and lava, though never complete immunity. The protection is directly related to your affinity depth, and reaches 60% reduction at full depth. Punching enemies at full affinity will light them on fire. !d Once your fire affinity reaches 50%, you will start to take damage periodically when touching water sources. This damage will not take you down below 75% health and will not occur if lower.

subitem.name: Nature Affinity
subitem.desc: Nature affinity gives you additional seeds and saplings when harvesting plants from around the world. At 50% depth, you will gain the Thorns effect, causing melee attackers to take damage (similar to the armor enchant). This damage increases at 75% affinity and at full affinity. At full nature affinity you also slowly regenerate hunger in direct sunlight. At full nature affinity, you can extend roots into the ground, allowing you to climb certain surfaces like a spider does. !d Nature affinity causes you to move slightly slower due to your roots. At full nature affinity depth, you lose hunger more quickly at night or in dark areas. !d At full nature affinity, you gain the aspect of a leaf on the wind, negating all fall damage and falling more slowly. You can sneak to fall at normal speed. This will still cause fall damage to be negated.

subitem.name: Ice Affinity
subitem.desc: Ice affinity causes attackers to be slowed. At 50% depth, while sneaking you will freeze water to ice in front of you, allowing you to make bridges as you move. At 100% depth, you can freeze lava to obsidian. !d All ice mages move slightly slower due to being cold blooded, unless on ice or water.

subitem.name: Lightning Affinity
subitem.desc: Lightning affinity causes you to run faster. The speed increase is directly related to your affinity depth, ranging from 1 to 30%. At 50% depth, you gain the ability to step up over one block high ledges. !d Unfortunately due to your affinity you are also sort of short out in water. You can also light nearby TNT and supercharge nearby creepers! Don't worry though, as you gain more control over your electric nature, you will be able to reduce the TNT and Creeper effects.

subitem.name: Life Affinity
subitem.desc: Life affinity causes you to very slowly regenerate additional life. The regen speed is directly related to your depth. This regen happens regardless of your hunger level. !d Due to your close ties with life, any time you kill something it makes you sick and nauseated for a while.

subitem.name: Arcane Affinity
subitem.desc: Arcane affinity causes all spells to cost 5% less mana, in addition to other mana reductions. At full depth, there is also a chance that upon casting a spell, you will gain the clarity effect, causing your next spell to cost 0 mana. !d As a disadvantage, all magical damage sources do more damage to you.

subitem.name: Ender Affinity
subitem.desc: Ender affinity gives you poison resistance at 50% depth, and at 75% depth you gain night vision automatically in dark areas. At full ender affinity, Endermen will not attack you, unless you attack them first. !d Due to your dark nature, your maximum health is reduced in light, and at higher ender affinity, it is reduced in water as well. Masters of the ender are rumored to have evolved beyond this weakness.

mechanic.name: Spell Creation
mechanic.desc: Creating spells is somewhat time consuming, but simple. First, learn some spell parts using an #5Occulus#0. Next, lay out the spell you want to create at an #5Inscription Table#0. Place the book from the inscription table on the lectern of your crafting altar structure, and throw in a #5Blank Rune#0. The book will guide you through the rest of the process, showing you what you need. When Etherium is required during the spell creation process, use a #5crystal wrench#0 to change the power type if necessary, then flip the switch on the multiblock. The structure will draw enough power, then turn the switch off automatically. Once your spell is created, equip it and right click to name it and set the icon. Once you have done this correctly, the spell will be castable! Otherwise it will show the customization UI again when you cast.

mechanic.name: Infusion
mechanic.desc: #5Infusion#0 is a process in which AM armor will drain mana from your mana pool to repair itself. Due to this mechanic, all AM armor has low durability, and won't last in a prolonged fight. Taking the armor off will cause it to stop infusing - it must be equipped for the mechanic to function. If the armor is at full durability, there is no mana cost.

mechanic.name: Mana
mechanic.desc: Mana is your magical energy level. You gain more mana by increasing your Magic Level. !d Mana regenerates over time, but you can gain boosts to regeneration by eating a #9Mana Cake#0 or standing near an Obelisk, Celestial Prism, or Black Aurem with more than 10% charge. #9Mana Potions#0 and #9Mana Potion Bundles#0 can be used to give an instant boost to mana. Mana is represented by a blue bar on your HUD. You can use "#2/amuicfg#0" to toggle an option to show the actual numeric values of your mana.

mechanic.name: Magic Level
mechanic.desc: Magic Level represents your strength as a mage. As your Magic Level increases, so will your Mana and Burnout capacities. Magic level can be increased by casting valid spells. A valid spell cast is one that does what is intended, meaning casting fire bolt at a wall for an hour won't get you anywhere. Certain components that have valid targets more rarely award more magical XP towards the next level. Your Magic Level is represented by a blue number on your HUD. You can use "#2/amuicfg#0" to toggle an option to show the actual numeric values of your magic XP bar.

mechanic.name: Burnout
mechanic.desc: Burnout is your level of strain when casting spells. The higher your Burnout, the more mana each spell will cost. Casting more powerful spells will cause more Burnout. It will decrease over time. Gaining Magic Levels will give you a higher Burnout cap, allowing you to cast more spells before becoming completely fatigued. Your Burnout level is displayed as a red bar on the HUD. You can use "#2/amuicfg#0" to toggle an option to show the actual numeric values of your burnout.

mechanic.name: Summoning Rituals
mechanic.desc: Summoning Rituals are what are performed to call upon bosses in Ars Magica. See the #5bosses section#0 of this compendium for the rituals specific to each boss.

mechanic.name: Moonstone Meteors
mechanic.desc: On occasion, during the night, small meteors may crash down into the overworld. This is the only way to obtain moonstone ore. A full moon increases the odds of one spawning. The meteor always falls within 32 blocks of a player, and they will only ever fall on a biome's cover block. Meaning unless you have a house made of grass, it won't even hit your home. If you do have a house made of grass, then what is wrong with you? Didn't you ever read the three little pigs?

mechanic.name: Enchantments
mechanic.desc: AM adds a few useful enchantments to the game to assist in your ascent to magical mastery.

subitem.name: Magic Resistance
subitem.desc: As the name suggests, this enchant offers protection against magic damage. There are 4 ranks to the enchantment, and it goes on armor.

subitem.name: Soulbound
subitem.desc: Ever get tired of losing your gear on death? You can fix that now. The soulbound enchant can be applied to just about any item that accepts enchantments, and will cause that item to remain in your inventory on death. You will respawn with the item in the same slot in your inventory it was when you died. Soulbound has a max enchantment level of 1.

mechanic.name: Armor XP Infusion
mechanic.desc: Whenever you gain XP, any equipped armor will gain some too. The amount gained is equal to the total amount of XP you just gained divided evenly among all equipped armor pieces. Any armor can gain XP. Stored armor XP can be used at an #9Armor Imbuement Table#0.

mechanic.name: Silver Skills
mechanic.desc: Silver skills are skills inside the occulus that cannot be obtained in normal ways. To unlock a silver skill, the correct spell combination must be crafted, and then cast. There are a few rules to silver skill unlock combinations that will make them somewhat easier to decipher. !d 1.) All parts required to unlock a silver skill will be in the #9same tree as the silver skill itself#0. !d 2.) All silver skills require between #9 2 and 4 components and/or modifiers to unlock#0. !d 3.) Shapes do not matter in unlocking a silver skill. #9Any shape can be used#0. !d 4.) The combination #9does not have to be in any specific order#0. As long as the correct components are present, it will work. !d 5.) The components/modifiers #9all have to be in the same stage#0. !d 6.) The components and modifiers #9will logcally make sense with the silver skill#0. For example, Firestorm won't require drown. !d 7.) The spell to unlocka silver skill may not be the most practical for common use.

guide.name: Foreword
guide.desc: Ars Magica began as my first foray into modding. I have been developing software professionally for about 11 years as of AM2's release, but haven't done much game design. I loved the game of Minecraft, but felt that it would be the perfect place for a magical world. So I began, and who would have thought I would enjoy it so much. I have spent literally hundreds of hours developing AM1 and AM2. With some good tutorials and a bit of luck, I managed to figure out how to write AM1. Now I have taken what I learned, solved some of the problems that came up (and probably introduced twice as many more), and have made Ars Magica 2. I want to thank all of the people who helped this mod come to be what it is today, my beta testers, everyone who helped me with code, models, and texturing - this wouldn't be what it is without you. And to you, the player, I hope that you have as much fun playing this mod as I did making it. !d Happy Casting! !l ~Mithion

guide.name: Using this Compendium
guide.desc: This compendium is set up to unlock entries as you get to them, to somewhat guide you through the getting started process of the mod. You will be notified when you unlock a new entry. Categories with new items in them will shimmer, and new entries themselves will have a crescent moon marking them as new. !d If you prefer to not have this, you can disable it in config by changing "Staged Compendium" to false. This compendium is #9intra-linking#0. Any item you hover over that has green text can be clicked and you will jump to the entry for that item. !d This compendium also leaves a breadcrumb trail, meaning you can step back through in reverse order through pages you have visited.

guide.name: The Ars Magica UI
guide.desc: The act of picking up a compendium has unlocked the arcane magics within you. You now have the AM2 HUD activated. To configure this UI, at any time, enter the command "#2/amuicfg#0". This will open a drag and drop configuration interface. Make your changes and press ESC to save them.

guide.name: Spell Components 101
guide.desc: Spells are comprised of #4shapes#0, #9components#0, and #2modifiers#0. Shapes dictate how the spell targets things, Components dictate what the spell does to the things it targets, and Modifiers change certain aspects of spells. A #4shape#0 can only appear once in a single spell. Shapes can be chained together to create spell stages, for example, a "Projectile AoE". Components can be added once per spell stage. As for modifiers, a single aspect of a spell can be modified three times per stage. What this means is that if you have modifiers that change multiple parts of a spell, they may lock out other ones that modify the same stats if the total stat modifier for the shape is equal to three. The compendium will only show you the shapes, components, and modifiers you already know, or are eligible to learn.

guide.name: Your First Spell
guide.desc: To make a spell, you will first need to create an #5Occulus#0 and unlock at least one spell shape and one component. You start with three blue skill points to make this possible. Then, craft a writable book and head over to your #5Inscription Table#0. Place the book in the inscription table. !d There are three sections of the Inscription Table UI that are of note. The source region is the large grey square at the top, and will contain all of your known shapes, components, and modifiers. The Shape Group section is identified by brown squares. There are multiple brown squares as multiple shape groups can be created. Finally there is the Spell Grammar section, which is the gray rectangle at the bottom. !d Create #5Shape Groups#0 by dragging shapes and/or modifiers from the source region to any of the shape groups in the UI. You can create multiple shape groups in the same spell, three by default. Each shape group can have up to four shapes/modifiers. Shape groups cannot contain components. A good way to think about it is that shape groups are different means of targeting things with the spell, then the spell grammar is what the spell actually does. !d Once your shape groups are created, drag the spell parts you want, in order, from the source region to the spell grammar section. The spell grammar section can contain spell shapes, components, and modifiers in addition to the shape groups. Once your combination is completed, go to your #5Crafting Altar#0 and place your book containing the spell recipe on the lectern. Throw a #5blank rune#0 into the middle of the crafting altar to begin the process, then follow the book's prompts. The book itself is worth reading as well, as it contains a recap of what the spell recipe is for, the materials list for the spell and an affinity breakdown of the spell. Note that certain crafting altars can only craft spells that are so powerful. Too much power and bad things can happen. See the entry on the #5Crafting Altar#0 for more information.

guide.name: A Few Recommended Spells
guide.desc: When starting out, it's recommended to make sure you take at least one #9Shape#0 and one #9Component#0 in the Occulus, lest you find yourself unable to make any spells. If you do this, you can either go looking in dungeons for #9Infinity Orbs#0, or try to fight a boss or two to get some more. If you're feeling cheaty, you can also use the /respec command. !p Here are a few sample spells to get you started: !d Basic Defense: !l Projectile + Physical Damage !d Stay Alive: !l Self + Regeneration !d Time to Mine: !l Touch/Projectile + Dig !d Clear Leaves: !l Projectile + Wizard's Autumn !d Fast Travel: !l Self/Projectile + Leap + Slowfall + Haste + Gravity Well

guide.name: Gaining Magic Levels
guide.desc: You gain magic levels by casting spells. You don't gain magic XP if the cast isn't successful, and there are diminishing returns on a cooldown, so spamming spells to grind won't get you anywhere. Casting spells also modifies your affinity. See #5Mechanics -> Affinity#0 for more information.

guide.name: Obtaining Skill Points
guide.desc: You get skill points primarily by leveling up. At each even level, you will gain one skill point. Levels 2-20 award blue skill points, 22-40 award green skill points, and 42-50 award red skill points. Additional points can be obtained by fighting bosses, trading with villagers, and exploring. You choose how you want to go about it! When viewing unlockables in the #5Occulus#0, hovering over the item will display #9text that matches the skill point color needed to unlock it#0.

guide.name: The Etherium System
guide.desc: Ars Magica contains a unique power system called #5Etherium#0. Etherium is generated from an #5Obelisk#0. An Obelisk will stream to other powered blocks within a 10 block radius. To extend the range of the Obelisk, you can place #5Etherium Conduits#0 within the 10 blocks of the obelisk. Each conduit also projects a radius of 10 blocks in which it can relay power from the obelisk, essentially extending the range in a chain. !d There are multiple types of Etherium. Different types of Etherium can be generated by other blocks, suck as #9Light Etherium#0 from a #5Celestial Prism#0 or #4Dark Etherium#0 from a #5Black Aurem#0. All Etherium types have the same transmit rules as the Obelisk, and can be extended by Etherium Conduits.

guide.name: Types of Etherium
guide.desc: There are three types of Etherium, by default. Addons to the mod can register new Etherium types, but the defaults are Light, Neutral, and Dark. See structures for crafting and variations of each of these. Each type of Etherium affects machines in a different way, and has advantages and disadvantages. You will also need all three types of Etherium available for spell crafting, as certain shapes, components, and modifiers can require different types of Etherium. Certain machines can only run on certain types of Etherium, and some machines require multiple types simultaneously.
